block.p: A lesson learned by NBC from lower-than-expected ratings for the Summer Olympics: five hours a day is too much. In four years, when NBC carries the Summer Games from Athens, a half-hour is likely to be cut, said Dick Ebersol, the chairman of NBC Sports.

Through eight days, NBC's 14.7 rating, with a 26 share, is down 16 percent from the 1988 Summer Games in Seoul, South Korea, the last time NBC carried an Olympics from such a distant time zone. (Each rating point equals 1.01 million television households. Share represents the number of televisions in use that are tuned to a particular program.)

The 14.7 rating is also 21 percent lower than the rating from the 1992 Games in Barcelona, Spain, and 35 percent lower than from the Atlanta Games four years ago.
NBC decided to add a half-hour, from 7 to 7:30 p.m. Eastern, to its coverage in Sydney. In Atlanta, NBC carried the Olympics from 7:30 p.m. to midnight, but went past midnight.
